Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for the 2014 Career Workshop for Women and Minorities in Computer Architecture (CWWMCA)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposal requests travel funds enabling students to attend Career Workshop for Women and Minorities in Computer Architecture (CWWMCA-2014). The workshop will be held in Cambridge, United Kingdom, in conjunction with the 47th Annual IEEE/ACM International Symposium on Microarchitecture (MICRO). The CWWMCA workshop focuses on the technical and career development of women and other minorities in the research field of computer architecture. The main workshop will be sponsored by ACM SIGMICRO as well as other industrial companies.

The support will go a long way towards including participation of women and minority students in a leading computer architecture workshop/conference and thereby enhancing the potential for their joining university faculty and/or the information technology workforce in the near future. Special funding will be provided for companion travel grants to support attendees with either disabilities, or a parent of an infant less than one year old, who cannot travel without the infant and a care provider for the infant. These efforts are anticipated to broaden the participation in the workshop and the main conference and, subsequently, the research field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this proposal is to request travel support funds that enable students to be able to defray the costs associated with traveling to and attending Career Workshop for Women and Minorities in Computer Architecture (CWWMCA-2014). The workshop has been held in Cambridge, United Kingdom, in conjunction with the 47th Annual IEEE/ACM International Symposium on Microarchitecture (MICRO). CWWMCA is a workshop that focuses on the technical and career development of women and other minorities in the research field of computer architecture.

In addition to the funds requested by this proposal from NSF, the workshop has been sponsored by ACM SIGMICRO as well as IBM.

Intellectual Merit The Career Workshop for Women and Minorities in Computer Architecture provides a forum for sharing advanced academic and industrial research work focused on computer architecture and career development advices for women and minorities in academia, industrial and government labs. The workshop covers a wide range of topics with two featured keynote speakers, Professor Margaret Martonosi (Princeton) and Professor Kunle Olokotun (Stanford) as well as a number of invited talks and a panel focused on career development for women and other minorities in the field of computer architecture. Invited speakers are from universities in the United States and Europe as well as from industrial research labs, including Dr. Alan Bivens (IBM Research), Professor John Cavazos (University of Delaware), Professor Natalie Enright Jerger (University of Toronto), Dr. Rosemary Francis (Ellexus Ltd), Professor Ruby Lee (Princeton University), Professor Jason Mars (University of Michigan), Professor Lingjia Tang (University of Michigan), and Dr. Greta Yorsh (Queen Mary University of London). 

Broader Impacts Support from this NSF grant has been distributed to students who may otherwise be unable to attend the CWWMCA workshop as well as to cover the registration cost of the invited speakers from the United States. Our grant selection process gave priority to US citizens and permanent residents, with special consideration to members of under-represented groups and participants from universities that do not have a strong tradition in the computer architecture research domain, in order to expand the workshop and conference participation. Furthermore, special funding was set aside to provide for Companion Travel Grants to support attendees with either disabilities, or a parent of an infant less than one year old who cannot travel without the infant and a care provider for the infant. These efforts are anticipated to broaden the participation in the workshop and the main conference and, subsequently, the research field.

Outcomes Overall, we received a total of ten student travel grant applications from universities including University of California at Irvine, Texas A&M University, Princeton University, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, University of Texas at Austin, University of California at San Diego, University of California at Santa Barbara, and Rutgers University. All student applications were considered for full funding. This included three female students and seven students from the under-represented ethnics groups including African Americans and Hispanic Americans.  Five of the awarded students were able to attend CWWMCA and took advantage of the travel grants while the remaining five students were unable to attend because of reasons other than the travel cost.
